ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Mutiny of Military Forces of Burkina Faso (1987-2014)
NOTES: Burkinabe soldiers left their barracks, firing gunshots into the air and looting shops on Tuesday night to protest the conviction of five soldiers in a sex scandal, a military source said Wednesday. A youth was allegedly killed by a stray gunshot during the incidents.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Mutiny of Military Forces of Burkina Faso (1987-2014)
NOTES: Gunfire rocked Ouagadougou, the capital, for more than three hours overnight on Wednesday in what an army source said was a protest by soldiers against arrests of their colleagues. The shooting came from two military camps, one in Ouagadougou and one on its outskirts. Defense Minister Yero Boly called for calm but did not give an explanation for the episode, which he said had wounded about a dozen people.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Traders whose shops were looted/vandalized during demos by mutinying soldiers on Feb.22-23 protested around military camps to claim damages. The soldiers dispersed them after clashes between the two groups.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Mutiny of Military Forces of Burkina Faso (1987-2014)
NOTES: Gun shots were heard on the night of the 26th in Fada NGourma. It is thought that a group of soldiers protesting against the incarceration of some fellow soldiers were behind the disturbances.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Student protests were reported in Sabou and Kaya over the death of Justin Zongo.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Student protests were reported in Sabou and Kaya over the death of Justin Zongo.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Students burned a police station in Boura during demos over the death of Justin Zongo. Police were reportedly not present.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
ACTOR2: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (1987-2014) Gendarmerie
NOTES: Students in Leo protested over the death of Justin Zongo in Koudougou and clashed with gendarmes after attacking and burning a police station and at least one video.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Mutiny of Military Forces of Burkina Faso (1987-2014)
NOTES: Soldiers fired into the air and blocked the western entrance to Fada N'Gourma following the arrest of a soldier. After receiving reinforcements from Tenkodogo, they released their comrade.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Mutiny of Military Forces of Burkina Faso (1987-2014)
NOTES: Gunfire by suspected mutinying soldiers was heard for 3 hours in Ouagadougou. They were allegedly expressing their anger over the arrest of a soldier.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Mutiny of Military Forces of Burkina Faso (1987-2014)
NOTES: Protests by mutinying soldiers were reported in Gaoua.

ACTOR1: Mutiny of Military Forces of Burkina Faso (1987-2014)
NOTES: Burkina Faso soldiers on Tuesday fired a rocket at the main courthouse in Fada NGourma, a day after freeing a comrade from jail and blocking entry to the eastern city, witnesses said.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Mutiny of Military Forces of Burkina Faso (1987-2014)
NOTES: Suspected protests were carried out by mutinying soldiers at the 11-78 camp on the road from Po, where gunfire was heard.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Mutiny of Military Forces of Burkina Faso (1987-2014)
NOTES: Soldiers protested and fired into the air in Banfora following a speech by President Compaore.

NOTES: The mayor of Ouagadougou and number three of Burkina Fasos ruling party, Simon Compaore, was injured when angry soldiers ransacked his home, an associate said Wednesday.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Hundreds of high school students protested violently on Thursday at Tenkodogo and set fire to government buildings.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: A prisoner was killed and several other injured during a riot in a prison in Bobo-Dioulasso.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Students in Po staged a 48-hour strike and protested, but no incidents were reported.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Students in Tiebele protested and burned the police station in their area as well as the house of a police officer over a dispute with him.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Organisers said tens of thousands of people across Burkina Faso marched Friday in protest against the regime of President Blaise Compaore.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Organisers said tens of thousands of people across Burkina Faso marched Friday in protest against the regime of President Blaise Compaore. There was an impressive turn-out in the capital Ouagadougou.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: CDP: Congress for Democracy and Progress
NOTES: The provincial HQ of the CDP and the ALCV was burned by angry students. The students clashed with CDP activists causing a number of injuries.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Thousands of people across the landlocked African country marched in protest against Compaores regime during the day.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Burkina Faso (1987-2014)
NOTES: Shots were fired Thursday inside the compound of Burkina Faso President Blaise Compaore, according to an AFP journalist.The fire from heavy and light weapons came from the barracks of the presidential guard which is located inside the 20-hectare compound.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Catholic Christian Group (Burkina Faso); Women (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: The Association of Catholic Women in Manga staged a peace march in the context of mutinying soldiers and ongoing student protests.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Soldiers from three barracks took to the streets of the Burkina Faso capital overnight, firing into the air and pillaging as their mutiny entered a third day, an AFP journalist reported Saturday. A group of mutinous soldiers in the early hours of 15 April 2011 also besieged the premises of Savane FM, a Ouagadougou-based privately-owned radio station and vandalized the station.

ACTOR1: Government of Burkina Faso (1987-2014)
ACTOR2: Mutiny of Military Forces of Burkina Faso (1987-2014)

ACTOR2: Mutiny of Military Forces of Burkina Faso (1987-2014)
NOTES: Coup/Military takeover: Burkina Faso President Blaise Compaore left the capital Ouagadougou early Friday amid a mutiny by his personal guard that has spread to other barracks, a military source said.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Hundreds of shopkeepers set fire to the headquarters of Burkina Fasos ruling party Saturday, saying they were angry at soldiers who looted and destroyed their merchandise and at the government that did not stopped it.

NOTES: Soldiers in Tenkodogo fired gun shots in the air in several neighbourhoods of the city.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Mutiny of Military Forces of Burkina Faso (1987-2014)
NOTES: Mutinying soldiers allegedly attacked and robbed Ghanaian traders in Po and the Dakola area near the Ghanaian borders. No casualties were reported.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Burkina Faso's ambassador to France was named the African countries new prime minister Monday as police joined soldiers on a rampage and students staged violent protests against President Blaise Compaores regime.

NOTES: 4 students were wounded during clashes with police during protests in Manga. The students set a police station on fire eduring the event. The mayor of a nearby town was also hit by a stray bullet during the protest.

NOTES: Following the introduction of a curfew in Ouahigouya after the recent mutinies, a number of people, including some children, were allegedly beaten by partially uniformed assailants for violating the curfew.

NOTES: Firing by mutinying police was also reported in Bobo-Dioulasso.

NOTES: An outbreak of ethnic violence left two people dead and 25 injured in Burkina Fasos Solenzo region, prompting authorities to impose a nighttime curfew, officials said Wednesday.The violence between the indigenous Bwaba and migrant Mossi ethnic groups broke out after a traditional initiation ceremony on Monday night, local governor Siaka Prosper Traore told AFP from Solenzo in north-east Burkina Faso.

NOTES: Thousands of students on Monday took to the streets of Burkina Fasos capital burning tires and chanting in support of teachers who are demanding better conditions.Angry students also entered the education ministry, destroyed computers, smashed windows and burned documents on the streets outside.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Mutiny of Military Forces of Burkina Faso (1987-2014)
NOTES: Soldiers in Bobo-Dioulasso were reported continuing to fire in the air and engaged in looting as part of their ongoing mutiny.

NOTES: Angry troops again rampaged through Burkina Fasos second largest city Thursday, firing shots into the air and looting businesses, residents said.

NOTES: Arrests: The Burkina Faso military has arrested 93 soldiers for alleged involvement in a mutiny, an officer told AFP, after disgruntled troops wreaked havoc in the economic capital for days last week.

ACTOR1: Government of Burkina Faso (1987-2014)
NOTES: Non-violent activity: The government of Burkina Faso, faced with public unrest and army mutinies since February, has replaced all the governors of the west African countries regions, it has announced.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Hundreds of Ministry of Economy and Finance employees protested to demand equality in the distribution of pooled funds.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Various trade union groups and CVCC members marched in Banfora to demand the end of the technical unemployment at SN-SOSUCO.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Members of the technical and support staff of the universitiesof Burkina Faso (ATOS) union staged a 48-hour sit-in at the university of Ouagadougou to demand housing allowances.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Employees of the tax department in Ouagadougou went on strike and staged a sit-in for better working conditions.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)

A Fulani herder was hit in the head by a machete during the incident before other Fulani drove off Bombore attackers. The cause of the incident was allegedly some livestock crossing a farmers field.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Workers of the National Blood Transfusion Center (CNTS) observed a 48-hour sit-in in Ouagadougou in favour of their demands.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Workers of the Ludic Lydia company gathered at the Labour Exchange of Ouagadougou to demand the dissolution of staff delegation, backpay, a reduction in the number of working days and the departure of 4 executives of the company.

NOTES: Due to the Tuareg rebellion in Mali, thousands of Malians fled into Bodo-Dioulasso. Many other Malians fled to other neighboring countries.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (1987-2014)
NOTES: After the car of the minister of justice narrowly avoided hitting a pedestrian, his bodyguards allegedly beat up the man. The justice minister was later fired over the incident.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Students in Koudougou staged a 48-hour strike in memory of students who died in violence last year. They marked the beginning of the strike with a peace march.

NOTES: Workers in the Regional Hospital Center (CHR) Tenkodogo, through the National Union of Workers of human and animal health section Boulgou (SYNTSHA / BLG), observed a sit-in against alleged misuse of hospital property and issues with the hospital sanitation staff.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: People gathered outside of a police station to protest the beating and arrest of a man by the police after a sporting event. The mayor arrived and defused the situation, securing the mans release.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (1987-2014)
NOTES: A resident of Reo was beaten by police on his way back to Ouagadougou. He was then taken to a nearby police station.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: The Burkinabe opposition marched against the proposed constitutional referendum on term limits.

ACTOR1: MNLA: National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: MAA: Arab Movement of the Azawad (Splinter Faction); HCUA: High Council for the Unity of Azawad; CMFPR: Coordination of Patriotic Movements and Forces for Resistance; CPA: Azawad People's Coalition
ACTOR2: MAA: Arab Movement of the Azawad
NOTES: Agreement: Rebel groups from northern Mali, including the MNLA, HCUA, MAA, another MAA faction, the CMFPR, and CPA have signed an agreement in Ouagadougou to end hostilities and unite ahead of negotiations with the Malian government in Algiers.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Residents of Djibo have demonstrated to demand the maintenance of the Djibo-Kongoussi roadway.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: The representative of the Anti-Referendum Collective (CAR) to District 11 in Ouagadougou was assaulted after the representative refused to leave the CAR, injuring him.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Residents demonstrating to demand road maintenance were violently dispersed by security services, leading to several serious injuries.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Traders decided to march to city hall to demand the mayor speed up the process of rehabilitating the central market so they can open up shops again.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Teachers marched in Ougadougou on World Teachers Day, Oct. 8, demanding that the Minister for Secondary and Higher Education Moussa Ouattara stop the continuum system because there are not enough classrooms to accommodate students. Protest coincided with sit-ins across the country on October 8, 9 and 10.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Teachers hold sit-ins across the country to demand better conditions for education, including a stopping the continuum process for pre-schoolers, and adopting special status and housing allowance for education workers. Sit-ins nationwide on October 8, 9 and 10.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Teachers hold sit-ins across the country to demand better conditions for education, including a stopping the continuum process for pre-schoolers, and adopting special status and housing allowance for education workers. Sit-ins nationwide on October 8, 9 and 10.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Traders closed their shops and marched in the streets to demand the speedy construction of the central market in Dedougou.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Crowds gathering in Ouagadougou on Oct. 21 to protest the governments intention to submit a draft law to amend the term-term presidential limit (which would allow President Compaore to stand for re-election in 2015).

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Rioters used tree trunks and ropes to barricade National Highway 3 on the morning of Oct. 23, preventing all vehicles from leaving Ouagadougou. Riots were in reaction to governments announcement of a draft bill to amend the two-term presidential limit.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Teachers sit-in at the Governorate of Hauts-Bassins to protest education policies.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Christian Group (Burkina Faso); Muslim Group (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Leaders of the Catholic communities, evangelical, Islamic and traditional religion gathered at the municipal stadium in Ouagadougou to pray for peace.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Protests in streets of Bobo-Dioulasso on Oct. 27. To keep parliament from voting on a constitutional amendment to the presidential two-term limit. Part of a call for civil disobedience by political opposition leader Zephyrinus Diabre.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Protests in streets of Ouagadougou on Oct. 27. To keep parliament from voting on a constitutional amendment to the presidential two-term limit. Part of a call for civil disobedience by political opposition leader Zephyrinus Diabre.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Hundreds of protesters in the streets in Dedougou on Oct. 28 to protest the upcoming parliamentary vote.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Hundreds of protesters in the streets in Banfora on Oct. 28 to protest the upcoming parliamentary vote. No reports of security forces present.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Rioters protested in Bobo-Dioulasso on Oct. 28 and destroyed a statute of Blaise Compaore. Police fired tear gas.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Thousands of rioters in the streets of Ouagadougou on Oct. 28. Rioters burned tires and threw rocks. Police fired tear gas and water cannons. Riots trying to stop parliament from voting on a constitutional amendment to the presidential two-term limit.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Trade unions and civil society go on strike and march in streets in Banfora to demand better costs of living and school accessibility.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Trade unions and civil society go on strike and march in streets in Dedougou to demand better costs of living and school accessibility.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Protesters and trade unions go on strike and march in the streets of Ouagadougou to demand better costs of living and school accessibility.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Trade unions and civil society go on strike and march in streets of Bobo-Dioulasso to demand better costs of living and school accessibility. Riots break out.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Tens of thousands rioted and burned the Assemblee Nationale du Burkina Faso, and set fire to cars outside. Rioters wanted to stop parliament from voting on a constitutional amendment to the presidential two-term limit. President Compaore declares state of emergency; cancels the declaration a few hours later. Reports of 30 dead and 100 wounded. Later reports clarify a total of 24 deaths, around 650 wounded, and 265 infringements during the uprising.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Riots throughout Ouagadougou; looting, burning homes of government officials, including mayor of Ouagadougou, Marin Casimir Ilbouda. One rioter killed by the police while attacking the home of President Comparoes brother, Francois Compaore.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: CDP: Congress for Democracy and Progress
NOTES: Rioters burn headquarters of ruling party CDP: Congress for Democracy and Change. Also attacked and burned the homes of government officials in Ouahigouya, including those of Yacouba Barry, Salif Diallo, and mayor Gilbert Noel Ouedraogo. Police threw tear gas. One body found in Ouedraogos home after the fire. 3 deaths total reported.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Protests in Borfora on Oct. 30 to prevent parliament from voting on a constitutional amendment to the presidential two-term limit.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Protests in Dori on Oct. 30 to prevent parliament from voting on a constitutional amendment to the presidential two-term limit.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Protests in Fada NGourma on Oct. 30 to prevent parliament from voting on a constitutional amendment to the presidential two-term limit.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Protests in Koudougou on Oct. 30, to prevent parliament from voting on a constitutional amendment to the presidential two-term limit.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
ACTOR2: Military Forces of Burkina Faso (1987-2014) Presidential Security Unit
NOTES: Protesters gather throughout the day at the Presidential Palace in Ouagadougou. Presidential guard fired shots in the air.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Several hundred rioters attacked Radiodiffusion Television du Burkina building. State radio and TV ceased operation.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Rioting at Watam Language Kaizer plant in Kossodo in northeastern Ouagadougou on Oct. 30.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Rioters burned several buildings in Bobo-Dioulasso, including the town hall and the residences of several borough mayors. Reports of 2 dead and 6 wounded.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Protesters gather at army headquarters at 7pm on Oct. 30, as Army General Honore Traore announces dissolution of government, calls off vote on constitutional amendment to two-term limit, and imposes a curfew.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Tens of thousands of protesters gather in front of the National Assembly on Friday morning demanding Compaores resignation and calling for former defense minister Kouame Lougue to take power. Leader of opposition Zephyrinus Diabre urges crowds to maintain pressure by occupying public space.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Looting of industrial and financial institutions in Bobo-Dioulasso.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Watam Language Kaizer plant in Kossodo in northeastern Ouagadougou looted on Oct. 31. Injuries reported.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Reports of looting along Independence Avenue in Ouagadougou on Oct. 31.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Several hundred rioters attacked the governors home in Banfora, using machetes, clubs, and stones.

ACTOR1: Government of Burkina Faso (1987-2014)
NOTES: Coup/Military takeover: President Compaore steps down as president. General Traore assumes position as acting Head of State (replaced by Gen. Zida on Nov. 1), creates a transitional government body for next 12 months, and announces elections will take place within 90 days.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Bissa Gold mining company looted on Nov. 1.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: PDC: Party for Development and Change
NOTES: Protesters gather at Radio Nationale du Burkina Faso (RTB) to hear Saran Sereme of the PDC: Parti pour le developpment et le changement. Military forces fire gunshots and teargas to disperse crowd before Sereme speaks. Military take control of RTB building. One person dead.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: UNIR/PS: Unity for the Renaissance/Sankarist Party; Citizens Broom
NOTES: Protests at Place de la Nation in Ouagadougou to hear from speakers from the Unity for the Renaissance/Sankarist Party and Le Balai Citoyen. Military forces dispersed crowd with teargas and gunshots fired in the air.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Burkina Faso (2014-2015)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Catholic Christian Group (Burkina Faso); Muslim Group (Burkina Faso); Mossi Ethnic Group (Burkina Faso); Government of Nigeria (1999-2015); Government of Ghana (2009-2017); ECOWAS: Economic Community Of West African States
NOTES: Agreement: Presidents of Nigeria, Senegal and Ghana meet with Burkina Fasos army chief Zida and leaders from Muslim, Catholic and Mossi ethnic groups to discuss transition in Burkina Faso. Parties agree to lift suspension on constitution and hold presidential and legislative elections in November 2015.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Burkina Faso (2014-2015)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Catholic Christian Group (Burkina Faso); Muslim Group (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Agreement: A framework for a transitional govt was unanimously accepted by political, religious, civil society and military leaders, effectively reopening government and resolving the recent coup until new elections are held.

ACTOR1: Government of Burkina Faso (2014-2015)
NOTES: Non-violent activity: Diplomat Michel Kafanda sworn in as transitional president, selected by a special committee chosing between 5 candidates to lead the country until elections next November. Zida, the army officer who took power after the fall of the president last month, was named Prime Minister, ensuring the military keeps a grip on the government during the transition.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Student teachers from the Institutde of Sciences protested for the reinstatement of an expelled classmate.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Workers at the Inata Mine went on strike from Dec 4 - 12, illegally occupying the mine to prevent access.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: CCVC: National Coalition against High Cost of Living, Corruption, Fraud and Impunity and for Liberty
NOTES: Thousands demonstrated in remembrance of Nobert Zongo, a journalist who was assassinated in 1998

NOTES: A march was held to commemorate the anniversary of the assassination of Norbert Zongo in 1998.

NOTES: A march was held to commemorate the anniversary of the assassination of Norbert Zongo in 1998.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Hundreds placed brooms on the grave of Thomas Sankara in a symbolic gesture to demand justice for the revolutionary leader who was assassinated in 1987.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: One hundred employees at the Ministry of Infrastructure and Transport went on strike to demand the resignation of the new minister. They were dispersed from the premises by security forces.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Dozens protested against the new Minister of Infrastructure and Transport, demanding his resignation.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Civil society organizations joined protesters from the Ministry of Transport, demonstrating for the resignation of Minister Dieguimde.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: More than 100 students at the National School for Public Health protested disciplinary measures, causing the school to shut down temporarily.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Rioters set fire to Truegold mining materials in Noogo. Police forces used tear gas to take control of the area while firefighters attended to the scene.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Youth sought out supporters the TrueGold Mining company in order to damage their property, including setting vehicles on fire and ransacking homes.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Youth sought out supporters the TrueGold Mining company in order to damage their property, including setting vehicles on fire and ransacking homes.

NOTES: Muslims, with Christian support, protested recent French journal Charlie Hebdos caricatures of the prophet Mohammed.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: 300 people demonstrated against the damage elephants cause to their farms.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: A group of youth accosted and temporarily detained a judge in front of the courthouse, in retaliation for recent arrests of protesters.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Students threw stones at the school and then ransacked the home of public secondary school headmaster Samate Santa and burned his vehicle in protest of disciplinary procedures against 5 students. They tried to attack the homes of other staff but were stopped by security forces.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Employees of Canal 3 television held a sit-in to demand increase in salaries and the CEOs resignation.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: CCVC: National Coalition against High Cost of Living, Corruption, Fraud and Impunity and for Liberty
NOTES: Protesters demonstrated against high fuel prices.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: CCVC: National Coalition against High Cost of Living, Corruption, Fraud and Impunity and for Liberty
NOTES: Protesters demonstrated against high fuel prices.

NOTES: Protesters demonstrated against high fuel prices.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: CCVC: National Coalition against High Cost of Living, Corruption, Fraud and Impunity and for Liberty
NOTES: Protesters demonstrated against high fuel prices.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: CCVC: National Coalition against High Cost of Living, Corruption, Fraud and Impunity and for Liberty
NOTES: Hundreds protested against high fuel prices.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of Burkina Faso (2014-2015) Presidential Security Unit
NOTES: The presidential guard stormed into the weekly Council of Ministers meeting at the presidential palace, demanding benefits.

ACTOR1: Unidentified Armed Group (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Protesters against the Presidential Guard were attacked by unknown assailants who damaged their vehicle, leaving one injured.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Protesters gathered at the Place de la Revolution to demonstrate against the Presidential Guard.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: In Ouagadougou and several other locations across the country, thousands of protesters marched to demand the dissolution of the presidential guard.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Civil society organizations and members of political opposition parties marched and gave speeches in favor of the dissolution of the Presidential Guard.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Inhabitants of Rimkieta, a neighborhood on the north-west side of Ouagadougou, blocked the road leading towards Nonsin to demand maintence and restoration of the neglected roadway.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Tidjania Muslims started intercepting Sunni Muslims in the streets to stop them from praying and destroyed their property. Many Sunnis started hiding in their homes without food or water.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Burkina Faso)
NOTES: Tidjania Muslims targeted Wahhabist Sunni Muslims, injuring several and causing material damages including setting fire to homes and places of worship.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Burkina Faso)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: SYNTB: National Union of Brewery Workers
NOTES: Brakina and Sodibo brewery workers went on strike, stopping all work at the factories in Ouagadougou and Bobo Dioulassoand, holding a sit-in to demand higher wages.

NOTES: Brakina and Sodibo brewery workers went on strike, stopping all work at the factories in Ouagadougou and Bobo Dioulassoand, holding a sit-in to demand higher wages.
